subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods, its urgent
msgSnippet: Private methods are difficult to test because, after all, they re private. If you adopt a convention that API methods are only presented via Java Interfaces
messageBody:
Private methods are difficult to test because, after all, they're
private. If you adopt a convention that API methods are only presented
via Java Interfaces instead of concrete classes then you don't care
about the way the implementers of the Interfaces are written. You can
then make non-API methods within the concrete implementation public
without implying that they are themselves API methods.

You would also write your API tests for the Java Interfaces and plug in
the concrete implementations to test them. If you need to write tests
for lower-level supporting methods within the concrete classes you can
do that separately, as appropriate and its easy because they are public.

> > Private methods support public methods. Therefore well
> tested public
> > methods will include the behaviour of the private methods.
> >
> > There is no real reason for directly testing private methods.
> >
>
> Domain objects support the GUI. By the logic above a well
> tested GUI will include the behavior of the domain objects,
> so there is no reason to unit test the domain objects :-)
>
> I've occasionally found reason to write unit tests for
> private, supporting methods. Often you loose efficiency
> testing supporting methods indirectly via their caller - such
> as in the case where you want to test their ability to
> properly handle a range of input values.
>
> Personally, I don't believe in private methods. I'd rather
> make everything public and testable and expose real APIs via
> Java Interfaces.
>
> To answer the original poster: google junit + "private methods"
